Jane
Okay. Good. How bout yourself?
John
Like my camera just failed.
Jane
Okay.
Jane
I'm as well. Like I'm on vacation. So it's a bit of a mess here. So perfect. Don't feel bad about it.
John
All right. That works. Cool. Thanks for giving me.
Jane
No problem. And I'm curious to hear what you're up to. Sounds interesting.
John
Whereabouts are you on vacation?
Jane
In for lauradale Mars?
John
Nice. Nice time of year to be down there.
Jane
Yeah, definitely. Where are you located?
John
City City?
Jane
Nice. Cool. That's where I fall out of on a usual basis. But usually, you know, you say getting on the, although it hasn't been that cold, but it's so nice to be out here. You know, where the cool sunny.
John
A, yeah, it's been crazy in City. It's been so warm. Yeah.
Jane
Well, there there was a cold.
Jane
Spell that like it didn't snow. It's like it's a crazy.
John
Yeah. I'm I was, I only recently moved to City over to summer. I was previously in Earth. Okay. Yeah, definitely different to what to the usual Earth Winters that's for sure.
Jane
Yeah. And what are you?
Jane
Alien, but what's the accent?
Jane
I hear. Yeah, yeah.
John
Yeah, it's definitely been dolled out a bit now at this stage, but, yeah, rise from ireland.
Jane
Very cool. I love our beautiful.
John
You been over?
Jane
I have, well, it's been a while.
Jane
But I have been a couple of times, yes. And.
Jane
You know, got a lot. Got a lump.
Jane
Of whiskey.
John
Absolutely. All right. See. I appreciate you jumping on. I know we get a bit of context. I'll kinda take it from the top. And so I'm CEO is AI, we're trying to automate customer feedback analysis for product team. So, what this means in reality, we basically ingest all of your qualified customer feedback. So call transcripts from sales, customer success calls, user interviews, customer support, tickets, social media, basically anywhere where the customers talking about your product, your company, we wanted to come to home for that. So we basically as a starting point for the one place. And then we use to basically automatically classify that into relevant buckets.
Jane
With the idea of, you know, like the product manager or whatever it using into the product in.
John
Yeah, exactly. And kind of, yeah, kind of value prop is like two twofold one of which is like bringing new data to that conversation that like previously was inaccessible or like sell it out somewhere in the organization.
John
And then secondly kind of even more B to B context. It's taking the lift off sales and CS teams actually like report back to the product on what they're seeing. And so it's kind of, you know, typically speaking, it's a problem for product team just trying to explain to CS and sales the information that they need. So we're getting it straight from the source with this. So we connect to like a lot of different. We have a large suite of integrations but basically the key ones to be like Jupiter if you have, if you have that on your, you know, we go on this call Jupiter. If you're using that with your sales team, alternatively, we can pull in actual like Zoom recordings. But wherever you're recording your information, we typically pull from there.
Jane
A quick question.
Jane
We don't use Jupiter. We use Saturn and we use like Neptun on the product side, you know, collect customer feed. Got one question. Like and I know, I think you're relatively early stage. Have you had any kind of, I guess… companies and I don't know what size of companies you're going after. So if you would be… you know, like they've gone through soft certification etcetera in terms of like access into those integrations, you know, even if it's read only like just giving you access into that. I don't know if it's like sensitive but like, you know, access information is a sensitive topic as.
John
Yeah. I mean, 100 percent. We take that very seriously. We actually partner with a service security company who have are essentially set.
Jane
But I don't…
Jane
Know if I hear all the screaming but they tell the kids they're gonna go somewhere a little bit more quiet.
John
No worries. Yeah, no, we definitely take that very seriously. We were like we have a pretty firm to quality around how we handle data. Typically, I typically speaking to data, we're getting as much crazy sensitive, but yeah, we have a pretty firm data policy.
Jane
Okay. Yeah. And kind of how far along are you, like what's the size of the company? Where is the product? Like is the product already launched? Or like?
John
Yep. So we're basically live right now with a few design partners. We've had a pretty incredible interest to try the product. We're being pretty deliberate and only bringing on companies who fit our target profile kinda get more into what that looks like. But yeah, we're recently launched so pretty early was like five people, but we're growing pretty fast.
Jane
Cool. And what is the target profile like? Just so I don't want to kind of take over the conversation. The reason, you know, first of all, thank you for the reach out and the reason from my perspective like responding, I don't think like this is by any means unique. You know… I'm a co founder myself but also as the product like within feel, I oversee it's a bit of a unique situation. I oversee both engineering, product, it and design. So I have like a relatively large remit, but in my product hat, I'm always looking for ways to kind of… create efficiencies in terms of like paratization and making sure we can do more with less and they doing the right things and a big part of that.
Jane
And I'm also very I'll call it data driven… in my, I guess as a person in general and in my product capacity specifically. So the more we can distill, you know, client feedback, sales feedback, customer success, feedback, et cetera, the better it is and for us it to, we also have basically four four products in the service or you can call it five products. So there's kind of a lot going on which makes it an even more kind of acute problem if you will.
Jane
So just taking a brief look at what you're doing… sounds interesting in kind of in the realm of one of the things I'm looking at and kind I'm looking to try and figure out.
John
Yeah, 100 percent. See I can share a bit on our kind of like our ideal customer would be mid stage like series B on as with a sales team and ideally that they have a reasonably high volume of calls with the majority of their customer in call coming through calls, architect or product around… call data is like probably the most unstructured feedback you possibly get. It's a very kind of unique data set to work with. So we are specifically tailing that data type because that's when we find these really valuable insights. So typically what happens is you might get some data sets maybe 10% of your total interactions come in via chat. At that point, what you tend to see is that the chat data becomes more and more important. As soon as someone has enough confidence to start typing instead of saying, oh gosh, let me click a button. They’re immediately writing real code, solving problems and you can capture that moment. So we believe that we could provide a significant amount of value to organizations that have a meaningful portion of their customer contact via phone.
